# Is Your Process Data Spread</br>Smooth or Chunky?

::: {.bigbold style="text-align: center;"}
Just the Facts
:::

::: {style="text-align: center;"}
DOFPro Team
:::

![](../../DOFPro_D7_Black_Red_Flame_No_Background_Cropped.png){.absolute left="25%" top="-45%" width=50%}


## Data Pairs

::: {.fragment .absolute top=15% left=0%}
Often, engineering process data appear with a dependent, or
measured, variable as a function of an independent, or set, variable
i.e., pressure as a function of temperature, or flow rate as a function
of time.
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=40% left=15%}
$$y = f(x)$$
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=55% left=0%}
Due to (always present) measurement uncertainty and/or process
variability,
:::

::: {.fragment  .absolute top=70% left=15%}
$$y_i = y_\mathrm{true} + \varepsilon_i = f(x_i) + \varepsilon_i$$
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=85% left=0%}
The question is how to determine $f(x)$.
:::


## Data Plots

::: {.fragment .absolute top=10% left=0%}
The human visual system is very good at seeing if a plot of data is a
straight line or almost a straight line. A number of functions can be
plotted as a straight line with a change of coordinates, typically from
linear to logarithmic.
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.absolute top=35% left=2%}
**Original</br>Function**
:::
::: {.absolute top=35% left=33%}
**Linear</br>Form**
:::
::: {.absolute top=35% left=65%}
**Coordinate Scale</br>For Linear Plot**
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.absolute top=50% left=0%}
$y = b x + a$
:::
::: {.absolute top=50% left=28.5%}
$y = b x + a$
:::
::: {.absolute top=50% left=62% style="font-size: 60pt;"}
$x$ – linear, $y$ – linear
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.absolute top=60% left=0%}
$y = ae^{bx}$
:::
::: {.absolute top=60% left=24.5%}
$\ln y = \ln a + b x$
:::
::: {.absolute top=60% left=62% style="font-size: 60pt;"}
$x$ – linear, $y$ – log (semi-log)
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.absolute top=70% left=0%}
$y = a10^{bx}$
:::
::: {.absolute top=70% left=19%}
$\log_{10} y = \log_{10} a + b x$
:::
::: {.absolute top=70% left=62% style="font-size: 60pt;"}
$x$ – linear, $y$ – log (semi-log)
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.absolute top=80% left=0%}
$y = ax^b$
:::
::: {.absolute top=80% left=22%}
$\log y = \log a +b\log x$
:::
::: {.absolute top=80% left=62% style="font-size: 60pt;"}
$x$ – log, $y$ – log (log-log)
:::
:::

## Comparisons

- The data are plotted on linear, semilog, and log-log plots, and fitted to all three functions.
- Compare noisy data generated by $y = ae^{bx}$, $y = ae^{bx}$, and $y = ax^b$.
- For each data set, the true values of $a$ and $b$ are $a=7$ and $b=3$.
- The best or "correct" fit is the one that looks the straightest and has $a$ and $b$ values close to 7 and 3 respectively.

## Nonlinear Least Squares

::: {.fragment .absolute top=15% left=0%}
A subtlety of data fitting on a transformed equation is that you have
also transformed the errors, and so you are no longer fitting the
original function. In other words, fitting
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=38% left=15%}
$\log y = \log a +b\log x$
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=51% left=0%}
is different from fitting
:::

::: {.fragment  .absolute top=64% left=15%}
$y = ae^{bx}$
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=77% left=0%}
With a spreadsheet or math software, you can do nonlinear least
squares data fitting, which gets around that issue. 
:::

## Nonlinear Least Squares (cont.)

::: {.fragment .absolute top=15% left=0%}
For the above function and your data set, you would guess values for
$a_\mathrm{fit}$ and $b_\mathrm{fit}$, then calculate for each data pair
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=30% left=15%}
$$y_{i_\mathrm{fit}}=a_\mathrm{fit} x_i^{b_\mathrm{fit}}$$
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=45% left=15%}
$$\varepsilon_i=y_{i_\mathrm{fit}}-y_i$$
:::

::: {.fragment  .absolute top=60% left=15%}
$$SSE=\sum \varepsilon_i^2$$
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=75% left=0%}
Then, by hook or by crook (or by using Solver) you would minimize
SSE by varying $a_\mathrm{fit}$ and $b_\mathrm{fit}$.
:::

## The Takeaways

1. The human eye is quite sensitive to straight lines and plotting data to examine for a linear relationship is a powerful way to estimate the functional relationship between pairs of data.
2. A linear function such as $y=bx+a$ appear as a straight line on a linear plot
3. An exponential function such as $y=ae^{bx}$, or $a\cdot 10^{bx}$ appears as a straight line on a semi-log plot.
4. A power law function such as $y=ax^b$ appears as a straight line on a log-log plot.
5. There are many other relationships you can try to see if you can get a straight line.
